At Mon, 17 Dec 2007 16:38:37 -0800,
Paul Jack <pjack@...> wrote:
> The OpenMBean specification is meant to ameliorate this shortcoming,
> and Heritrix uses Open MBeans exclusively. There is to my knowledge
> no universal OpenMBean connector that would allow non-Java programs
> to easily

Thanks for the information. According J. Steven Perry’s JMX book, open
mbeans seem to be more intended to deal with problems across Java
systems rather than between java & non-java systems. Non-java JMX/mbeans
implementations seem to me a pipe dream; and even if we write one for,
say, C, we still have to build interfaces for Ruby, Python, Perl, and
we still don’t have implementations for other languages.

> Happily, this should change shortly. We are working with several
> international partners to create a web services interface to Heritrix
> in the first few months of 2008.

Good news!

> If you or anybody else on the list has specific ideas/features they'd
> like to see in such an interface, please reply to this thread.
>
> > I’m pretty much agreed on this. I think that JMX will never be
> > sufficient for complete or near-complete solution for complete
> > remote control of heritrix (
>
> We're shooting for near-complete.
>
> > including delete of all information related to a job,
>
> The current Engine deleteJob method only deletes the job's
> subdirectory; if you're storing logs or BDBs on other disks they
> aren't affected. It doesn't seem like it would be hard to add a new
> JMX method to "fully delete" a job. Such a method would just scan the
> settings for a job and delete every file setting mentioned; would you
> mind opening a Feature Enhancement in JIRA for this?

Sorry, I missed that method in the new version. I am more familiar
with the last one. That seems reasonable to me, as long as you can
delete completed jobs as well as running ones.

> > management of completed jobs,
>
> Please say more about this. Other than full removal of a completed
> job, what other management features would you like to see?

The ability to query the job in the same way (with the same interface)
as is used on a running job. I don’t think that there should be two
ways to retrieve the status of a job: on a live job, to call the
Status attribute, and on a finished job, to retrieve the 3rd line of
the state.job file. You should be able to retrieve the arc files &
logs, using the same mechanism that is used to retrieve the arc files
& logs of a running job. If a job crashed, you should be able to move
the job from one machine to another & recover it. (Some of these last
ideas may be impractical or impossible.)

> > retrieval of logs & arcs, etc.);
>
> This is the only one I disagree with. Again, I wouldn't want to
> implement a whole entire file system inside of Heritrix. Though I
> suppose simple read-only streaming for large files may be desirable
> enough to warrant the extra effort, especially if we're embedding an
> HTTP service anyway.

It’s pretty trivial to add streaming of files to a decent HTTP
interface; a few lines of code.

In our service we give reports to the user which depend on being able
to retrieve & process the entire crawl.log, so it would be nice to
have a way to get complete copy of the logs with minimal effort.

best,
Erik Hetzner
